content: The "Business Improvement Act of 1993" allows contracts awarded to program participants before the enactment of the Act to be considered for business activity targets under the Small Business Act. SEC. 3. PROCUREMENT PROCEDURES. Section 8 of the Small Business Act is amended to allow participating agencies to enter into contracts with small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals through restricted competition or a price evaluation preference of up to 10 percent. Section 8 of the Small Business Act is amended to allow participating agencies to enter into contracts with small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals through restricted competition or a price evaluation preference of up to 10 percent. The term 'participating agency' refers to any Federal agency, except the Department of Defense. This authority is effective until September 30, 2000. ELIGIBILITY OF PAST DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS FOR SECTION 8(a) CONTRACT AWARDS. Section (8)(a)(1)(C) of the Small Business Act is amended to allow awarding contracts to small businesses owned and controlled by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals who have completed their Program Participation period. This applies to both competitive and sole source awards. The Small Business Act allows contracts to be awarded to small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals who have completed their Program Participation period, for both competitive and sole source awards. SEC. 5 amends Section 8(a)(1) of the Small Business Act by eliminating competitive contracts under subparagraph (D). SEC. 6 ensures continued access to business opportunities. Section 8(a)(3) of the Small Business Act is amended to require competition for contracts to furnish products or services to a participating agency if there are offers from 2 or more eligible small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals capable of performing the contract. The Small Business Act is amended to require competition for contracts to furnish products or services to a participating agency if there are offers from 2 or more eligible small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals capable of performing the contract. The head of a participating agency shall restrict the contract to a small business that has graduated from the small business and capital ownership development program prior to the date of solicitation issuance. The Small Business Act requires competition for contracts to furnish products or services to a participating agency if there are offers from 2 or more eligible small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals. The head of a participating agency shall restrict the competition for the award of a contract to small business concerns owned and controlled by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals upon request. A small business concern eligible for the contract resulting from a restricted competition must have graduated from the small business and capital ownership development program prior to the solicitation issuance date. The Small Business Act requires competition for contracts to furnish products or services to a participating agency if there are offers from 2 or more eligible small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals. The head of a participating agency shall restrict the competition for the award of a contract to small business concerns owned and controlled by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals upon request. A small business concern eligible for the contract resulting from a restricted competition must have entered into an agreement to subcontract a percentage of the award value to small businesses in the developmental stage of the minority small business and capital ownership development program. The Small Business Act requires competition for contracts to furnish products or services to a participating agency. Contracts awarded must ensure follow-on contracts for similar products or services are also awarded to small businesses. A participating agency is defined as any Federal agency, and a small business is defined as a business concern with not more than 1500 employees. SEC. 7. STUDY OF DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM PARTICIPATION TERMS BY INDUSTRY SECTOR; SUSPENSION OF DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM GRADUATIONS. The Small Business Act is amended to authorize a short-term study to determine program participation terms by industry sector for small businesses. Results of the study will be transmitted to key government officials within 1 year. The Small Business Act is amended to allow small business participation in programs until 1 year after enactment. Small businesses eligible for contracts on October 1, 1992, can continue participation until specified date. Small businesses eligible for contracts on October 1, 1992, can continue participation in programs until 1 year after final regulations are issued or until their eligibility expires. SEC. 8. COMPLIANCE WITH BUY INDIAN ACT. Federal agencies contracting with the Small Business Administration under section 8(a) of the Small Business Act for goods or services from economically disadvantaged Indian tribes are considered compliant with the Buy Indian Act. SEC. 9. UNIFORM PROCEDURES FOR CONTESTING STATUS OF CONCERNS. SEC. 9. UNIFORM PROCEDURES FOR CONTESTING STATUS OF CONCERNS. An amendment to the Small Business Act requires the Administrator to establish uniform procedures for contesting the status of a concern as a 'small business concern owned and controlled by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals' within 120 days.
